Nowadays, many songs are explicit… played in a variety of contexts without a whisper of protest. Do CD’s even have to display an Adult Content warning anymore?
 
But in the 1970’s, when I was a teen, explicit language was very much an exception in the pop music I knew. The success of a record was very much, at that time, long before the “wild wild west” of the Internet, connected to the AM and FM radio airplay it got, and strict FCC censorship laws applied to song lyrics at that time. Most sexual (and illicit drug or government protest) references had to be cloaked in metaphor… intimated in one way of another, not explicitly stated. Another trick at that time was to have the lead singer mutter and garble any words that might be objectionable.
 
So you can imagine how startled I was, attending a party in 1980, to hear the DJ suddenly put THIS record on. It was the dirtiest song lyric I had ever heard up until that time.
 
But it was— and still is— an incredible sounding record, and I remember going out to purchase that album the day after the party.
